Bare Metal STM32

A while back I had to develop a high speed monitoring system. After some research I decided to use a ARM STM32 MPU. The STM32 developers wrote 2 libraries: HAL & LL. HAL is easy to use because the programmer just needs to learn the so called high level API commands. LL on the other hand is a bit more difficult to use. This is due the fact that it uses a lot less functions. I decided to use HAL because I had zero experience with STM32 boards. After some coding the application worked but I did not understand what was going on. HAL works fine and quick but if a error or bug occures it is very difficult to solve it.

Luckly I learned some register programming in C for the MSP430FR5969. This is a Cortex M0 board, a lot easier to use than my STM32MP1 MPU, which contains a Cortex M4 and Cortex A7. The Code Composer Studio IDE offers the user a easy to use minimal coding environment for my MSP430. Keil IDE, the STM32 variant does not, the user needs to pay for a licence to write a program that is larger than 30kB. Other variants like System Workbench or STM32Cube IDE are bloated just like Keil and they are not easy to use if you want a minimal environment. After some digging I realised that the CMSIS and ST devs offer files for every STM32 board, these contain references to the memory locations of the chip. Combined with a Makefile, Text editor and debugger this would be the best experience possible (at least in my opinion of course).

My project is open source and free to use, it contains easy to use templates for the STM32 L476RG microcontroller. It works on Windows, OSX and GNU/Linux. Feel free to commit some code or to contact me if you have any questions.

In the future I will try to write some code for some other cortex chips. Also I'm trying to create a simular project for the MSP430 board so I can ditch the Code Composer Studio IDE.
